Authors:
Wataru Aoki, Naoki Endo, Shuji Ushijima, Masaki Fukuda,
Akiyoshi Yamada
Title:
Taxonomic revision of Japanese Tricholoma ustale and closely
resembled species based on multi-gene phylogenetic analyses and
morphological observation: two new Tricholoma species descriptions, T.
kakishimeji and T. kakishimejioides spp. nov.
Keywords:
Cryptic species, Ectomycorrhizal fungi, Poisonous
mushrooms
Abstract:
“Kakishimeji” identified as Tricholoma ustale (Fr.) P.
Kumm. and belonging to Tricholoma sect. Genuina is known as one of
common poisonous mushrooms in Japan. Kakishimeji contains the toxic
compound, ustalic acid, and causes digestive troubles. However, this
fungus is consumed in some local regions in Japan without any digestive
troubles. In this study, we aimed to clarify the probable
species-complex of “Kakishimeji”, based on the phylogenetic analysis. We
collected 79 basidioma specimens of “Kakishimeji” and related species
from various forest sites in Japan, and conducted multi-gene
phylogenetic analyses. As a result, “Kakishimeji” consisted of four
distinct phylogenetic clades based on any DNA regions tested. Of these,
two clades were included in the known species, i.e. T. stans and T.
albobrunneum, respectively. Another two clades consisted sister clades
to known species, i.e. T. pessundatum and T. ustaloides, respectively.
In addition, all four phylogenetic clades of Kakishimeji showed
difference in their spore and basidium size, respectively. Therefore, we
regarded the latter two clades as two new Tricholoma species, i.e. T.
kakishimeji and T. kakishimejioides.
